div1.p: Glennan reveals the costs of the new disinfecting building for the Shore Plant for the upcoming six months. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Letter from A. H. Glennan to the Adjutant General, June 25, 1901
div1.opener:
File -- FROM THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES
MARINE HOSPITAL SERVICE
* 1798 * U.S. * 1871 *
MARINE-HOSPITAL SERVICE
OFFICE OF MEDICAL OFFICER IN COMMAND
Havana, June 25, 1901.
Adjutant General,
Department of Cuba,
Havana.
Sir:
div1.p:
In reply to your letter of June 20, 1901, I have the honour to
state that outside of the ordinary operations of the Service for the
next six months there is contemplated, and now under consideration
by the Governor General, the erection of a new disinfecting building
for the Shore Plant, and the purchase of a steam tug. It is esti-
mated that the cost of running the Service for the period mentioned
will be about $15,000 a month, or $100,000 for the six months, as an
outside figure.
div1.closer:
Respectfully, A. H. Glennan Surgeon U.S.M.H.S.,
Chief Quarantine Officer
for the Island of Cuba.
